articles.title: LOVE LAKE SEBU
articles.subtitle: T'nalak
articles.body: T'nalak, is a weaving tradition of the T'boli people of South Cotabato, Philippines. T'nalak cloth is woven exclusively by women who have received the designs for the weave in their dreams, which they believe are a gift from Fu Dalu, the T'boli Goddess of abacá.
articles.body2:
#LoveThePhilippines
#lovesouthcotabato
lovelakesebu
articles.author: Information Office

articles.title: Please heart and share our Bahay Kubo
articles.subtitle: People's Choice Award
articles.body:
Ka-Agri, narito na ang mga kuhang larawan ng paborito ninyong Bahay Kubo ngayong taon. Kaninong Bahay Kubo kaya ang makakakuha ng "People's Choice Award"

I-Like at follow ang South Cotabato Provincial Agriculture Facebook Page para sa mga karagdagang updates. Mag-react ng heart at I-share ang inyong paboritong bahay kubo. Tulungan ang inyong napupusuang kalahok para Manalo ng "People's Choice Award"
articles.body2:
GUIDELINES:

1. Ang Official Facebook Page ng Provincial Agriculture Office ang tanging maglalagay ng mga larawang gagamitin sa online poll sa tulong ng Provincial Information Office.

2. Ang City/Municipal Representative ang pipili ng larawang gagamitin sa posting.

3. Tanging Heart Reactions sa mga larawan ang bibilangin ng OPAg.

4. Ang online poll ay may kabuuang 2% sa criteria para sa General Appearance ng Kubo.

5. Ang pagboto ay magsisimula sa July 13, 2023 12:00 ng tanghali hanggang July 16, 2023 12:00 ng hatinggabi.

6. Ang tatlong (3) kubo na may pinakamaraming heart reactions ang bibigyan ng titulong "People's Choice Award" and most heart award.

7. Ang tatlong (3) mananalo ay makakakuha ng tig-iisang Kubo bilang gantimpala maliban sa kubong mapapanalunan sa Major Awards.

8. Ang pagbinnbilang sa puntos para sa heart reactions ay ang sumusunod:

0-999-----0%
1000-2000-----0.5%
2001-3000-----1.0%
3001-4000-----1.5%
4001-5000-----2%

Like here: Pumunta sa South Cotabato Agriculture Office page
articles.author: PIA South Cotabato

articles.title: Love the Children Foundation, Inc.
articles.subtitle: and the Municipal Tourism Office are joining forces to enhance community empowerment and local tourism
articles.body: Love the Children Foundation, Inc. and the Municipal Tourism Office are joining forces to enhance community empowerment and local tourism. The organizations announced their collaborative venture which aims to provide accessible skills training for product development. This includes crafting bags and accessories, as well as furniture making. Those interested in acquiring these valuable vocational skills are invited to register at the Municipal Tourism Office. The move reinforces both parties' commitment to uplift local economies, cultivate artisanal talent, and foster sustainable development.
articles.body2: Now celebrating its 23rd year of unwavering service, Love the Children Foundation, Inc. is a testament to enduring humanitarian spirit. The foundation began its noble journey by providing sanctuary for orphans, abandoned, abused, and street children. More than just a safe haven, it extends comprehensive care encompassing food, education, and skills training, accompanying these children until adulthood. Remarkably, many of the individuals nurtured by the foundation have flourished into successful adults with college degrees and lucrative careers. To maintain their impactful operations, the foundation ingeniously operates food carts and other livelihood projects. The organization also gratefully accepts donations, welcoming all forms of support as it continues to make lasting change in these children's lives.
articles.author: PIA South Cotabato

articles.title: Bo’i Diwa Ofong
articles.subtitle: hails from the humble barangay of Lamdalag
articles.body:
Bo’i Diwa Ofong- hails from the humble barangay of Lamdalag, located in Lake Sebu, South Cotabato, and has seen seventy years of life unfold before her. She was but a young woman, aged between 28 and 30 years, when she was graced with the title of bo’i – an honorific given to female leaders within her community. As a bo’i, she has dedicated her life to the welfare of her fellow T'boli, selflessly resolving conflicts, settling disputes, and contributing to the continued sustenance of her people.

The secret behind her ascendance to this position of respect and authority does not lie in inherited wealth, possessions, or property; instead, it's rooted in her compassion and her profound love for her people. She underscores her belief that it's these innate qualities of love and care that have truly guided her on her leadership journey.
articles.body2:
As the youngest among eight siblings, Diwa Ofong found herself drawn to the art of abaca connecting at the tender age of 12 or 13 years. It was a skill she acquired and nurtured over a span of two years under the patient tutelage of her mother, who later introduced her to the intricate art of tying designs. Ofong is now proficient in an impressive repertoire of around fifty unique designs. She fondly recalls that half of these are cherished inheritances from her mother, while the others are products of her vivid dreams, bringing a unique blend of tradition and creativity to her work.

Book Consultant: Dr. Jennifer B. Tupas
Script Writer: Mr. Ronilo Muyco
Graphic Art: Mr. Reymark Ugak
articles.author: The Book Nook Lake Sebu

articles.title: A simple exchange of vows was shared earlier today, July  5, 2023 , at  the back of Municipal Hall, Poblacion, Lake Sebu.
articles.subtitle: Lake Sebu Municipal Mayor Floro S. Gandam officiating the wedding of  Mr. Jade Salvacion Dela Peña and Ms. Maryan Andales Egno both from Sition Blit, Barangay  Ned, Lake Sebu, South Cotabato.
articles.body: The ceremony was facilitated by Municipal Civil Registrar Office headed by MCR Mr. Garcia K. Alam, LPT, MPA. The ceremony also witnessed by the families and friends.
articles.body2: Please help me in congratulating this new couple with well wishes on their wedding day! May God continue to bless you both with good health, wealth and prosperity in the many years to come.

articles.title: The Department of Social Welfare and Development (DSWD)
articles.subtitle: implement the Balik Probinsya, Bagong Pag-asa Program (BP2)
articles.body: The Department of Social Welfare and Development (DSWD) continues to implement the Balik Probinsya, Bagong Pag-asa Program (BP2) which is open to all eligible Filipinos wanting to start a new in the provinces.
articles.body2:
The DSWD XII headed by Regional Director, Loreto Jr., V. Cabaya, in partnership with LGU Lake Sebu headed by Municipal Mayor Floro S. Gandam through MSWDO facilitated the releasing of livelihood assistance worth 50,000 and transitory assistance worth 50,000 with a total of 100,000 to Balik Probinsya, Bagong Pag-asa Program BP2 benificiary Ms. Anisa G. Tomara from Purok Malinong, Brgy. Lake Sebu, South Cotabato.

Present were Municipal Social Welfare Development Officer, Adela C. Dorego, RSW, MPA along with DWSD XII Regional Director, Loreto Jr., V. Cabaya, Social Welfare Officer III, Desiree N. Pingot, Project Development Officer II-DSWD, Mohammad T. Baunto, Project Development Officer-RPBO, Ruben A. Banggay Jr., Project Development Officer-PC, Angelita P. Paquibet, Project Development Officer-SUP, Reynaldo Bedonio Jr. and Project Development Officer II-BP2, Hanniya A. Sarip.

articles.title: Lake Sebu Travel Guide 2023: Experience the Culture of T’Boli Tribe
articles.subtitle: Perched in the highlands of South Cotabato is the town of Lake Sebu, home to the indigenous T’boli and Ubo tribes and an emerging eco-tourism and adventure destination in Southern Mindanao.
articles.body:
Known for its majestic waterfalls, lakes, rivers and springs, and with its rich biodiversity and culture, Lake Sebu is starting to hit big in the tourism landscape of the region. Its main attractions include Lake Sebu, the biggest of the three lakes that dot the town and an important watershed in the region being the source of water of the provinces of South Cotabato and Sultan Kudarat.

Aside from the lake, tourists also troop to this part of Mindanao to see the waterfalls in Barangay Siloton. A total of seven majestic waterfalls with the water coming from the outflows of the Lakes Sebu and Siloton. The first two waterfalls are easily accessible to tourists while the others require trekking. But the best way to see these waterfalls is by riding a zipline that passes above five of them!

With all the attractions that the town offers, it is without a doubt that Lake Sebu is one of the best places in the country to experience culture, appreciate the beauty of nature and enjoy thrilling adventure. A paradise on its own right, make Lake Sebu one of your unforgettable travel experiences in your journey to Mindanao.
articles.body2:
How to Get to Lake Sebu
General Santos – Lake Sebu
General Santos City is the usual jump off point to Lake Sebu. Philippine Airlines and Cebu Pacific have daily regular flights to General Santos City International Airport from Manila, Cebu and Iloilo.

From General Santos City’s Bulaong Terminal, there’s a direct van going to Lake Sebu.

General Santos – Marbel – Lake Sebu
Alternatively, you can catch a nonstop Marbel (Koronadal) bound Yellow Bus Line (YBL) from Bulaong Terminal, travel time is approximately one hour and fare is P100 (as of 2017). At Marbel Terminal, catch a van to Lake Sebu (travel time takes 1.5 hours) but schedule is unpredictable and limited. Alternatively, you may ride a bus going to Surallah, travel time is around half an hour and fare is P30 (as of 2017) and transfer to a jeepney stationed at Surallah Terminal going to Lake Sebu, a forty-five minute journey for P50 (as of 2017) with last trip usually at six in the evening.

Davao City to  Lake Sebu
Take a bus from Davao Ecoland Terminal to Marbel. Travel time is at least four (4) hours and fare is around P350 (as of 2017). From Marbel Terminal catch a van straight to Lake Sebu or one via Surallah.

Going Around and Away
Habal-habal or motorbike is the main mode of transportation around the town, minimum fare is P10. Meanwhile, jeepneys going to Surallah regularly ply the main road of Lake Sebu with the last trip at around 4PM. If you miss the last trip, a habal-habal can take you to Surallah for P50 fare.

Where to Stay in Lake Sebu
A trip to Lake Sebu can be done on a day if you are coming from General Santos City but there are accommodations in town for those who prefer to stay a night or two.

School of Living Traditions
Sitio Lambanig, Barangay Poblacion, Lake Sebu, South Cotabato
Contact No: +63935-4569359 (Maria Todi)

The Dreamweavers Hill Resort
Sitio Sarisa, Lamdalag, Lake Sebu, South Cotabato
Budget: As low as P1000 for room good for 2
Contact No: 09173072767/09171230434
Email:thedreamweavershill@gmail.com

Punta Isla Lake Resort
Sitio Toku-fol, Lake Sebu, South Cotabato
Budget: As low as P1000 for room good for 2
Contact No: +63919515015/+639052895134
Email: reservations.puntaisla@yahoo.com
articles.author: Lakwatsero

articles.title: Lake Sebu fish kill destroys P20M worth of tilapia
articles.subtitle: JOB GENERATOR Growing tilapia in fish cages in Lake Sebu, South Cotabato, is a multimillion-peso industry that has generated employment for lakeside residents.
articles.body:
KORONADAL CITY—At least 1,000 fish cages containing about 200,000 kilograms of tilapia were ravaged by the latest fish kill in Lake Sebu town, South Cotabato province, last week, an official said on Monday.

Lake Sebu Mayor Floro Gandam said at least 250 tilapia growers would get aid from the local government to recover their losses estimated at P20 million.But officials who joined an emergency meeting which Gandam convened on Monday did not think the damage was extensive enough to place the town under a state of calamity.

Christopher Ofong, the municipal information officer, said the disaster risk reduction and management office decided against recommending the declaration of state of calamity because some criteria were not met, such as the condition that the fish kill should affect at least 20 percent of the population.
articles.author: BONG S. SARMIENTO
articles.body2:
Dissolved oxygen
The fish kill affected at least 10 subvillages in three of the town’s 19 barangays, Ofong said.Rudy Muyco, the municipality’s lake warden, said dissolved oxygen in the lake was “almost at zero level,” as shown by results of a water analysis conducted by the Bureau of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources.

Oxygen level in the lake would “naturally improve with regular heavy rainfall and eight to 10 hours of sunlight,” allowing fish to survive, Muyco said.But he said damage to the tilapia industry was expected to rise as the fish kill continued to hit some fish cages, which cover 16 percent, or 57 hectares of the lake’s total area.

Oversupply
Local officials attributed the fish kill to a phenomenon called “kemohung,” or “kamahong,” marked by sudden changes in the lake’s temperature. Usually occurring during the wet season, the phenomenon triggers the rise of sulfuric acid that eventually lowers the dissolved oxygen in the water.

The fish kill has worsened since it was first observed on Jan. 8, prompting growers to harvest their tilapia stock and flood wet markets in different parts of Soccsksargen (South Cotabato, Cotabato, Sultan Kudarat, Sarangani and General Santos) region.'

The resulting oversupply caused tilapia farm-gate prices to drop to an average of P100 per kilo. Tilapia stocks are usually sold in commercial markets at P130 to P150 a kilo.
